title: Enhancing Few-shot Keyword Spotting Performance through Pre-Trained Self-supervised Speech Models
author: Alican Gok (Bogazici University), Oguzhan Buyuksolak (Analog Devices), Osman Erman Okman (Analog Devices), Murat Saraclar (Bogazici University), ...
relevance_why: The paper addresses few-shot keyword spotting (FS-KWS), which is integral for low-resource audio applications. The methods proposed, particularly around dimensionality reduction and self-supervised learning, could enhance the robustness and efficiency of Haohe's audio generation and enhancement tasks.
background: Few-shot keyword spotting enables recognition of custom spoken keywords with only a limited number of training examples, addressing scalability challenges in traditional keyword systems.
contribution: This paper introduces a training framework combining self-supervised learning and a new loss function to improve keyword detection accuracy on limited training samples, achieving significant performance gains.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous FS-KWS methods struggled with accuracy and adaptability to new keywords due to reliance on large datasets and dense embeddings.
technical_comparison.novelty: This framework improves through the use of Sub-center ArcFace loss for inter-class separability and knowledge distillation from a robust teacher model to a lightweight student model.

key_innovation: The introduction of attention-based dimensionality reduction techniques alongside advanced loss functions for better keyword representation and accuracy in low-resource scenarios.
real_world_impact: This research fosters improved user experiences in hands-free interaction devices, making technology more accessible, particularly in battery-constrained environments.

new_terms.Few-Shot Keyword Spotting: **Few-Shot Keyword Spotting (FS-KWS)** refers to the ability of a system to recognize new keywords after being trained with only a small number of examples.
new_terms.Sub-center ArcFace Loss: **Sub-center ArcFace Loss** is a metric learning approach that enhances classification performance by introducing additional center embeddings for each class, improving intra-class compactness.
